comments.article: I'm downloading and listening to it on my iPod as I do culinary duties this Thanksgiving. I know what I'm thankful for.

Thanks for the link - I enjoyed it during breakfast today (GRRM's section is the first 16 minutes).

For me, I'd say science fiction, as with fables, can often be better than other forms in putting a particular idea in relief, where you can set something like race relations outside of our every day world and see it with more objectivity.

And as for the decline of science fiction's popularity, I'd say that while I loved it as a kid in the 70's, my taste have turned to fantasy. It might be that as a kid we had all these visions of computers and space stations as this great new universe to explore, but now we've seen them, we get pummelled by them by ads, and we know they don't bring the adventure we crave. And so we wish to get away from all the technology and back to grasping a solid piece of steel in our hands. Back to campfires and horses and the land, to the sense of magic and mystery that today's world seems to be lacking in.

I heard you on "To the Best of Our Knowledge"(?), followed by the LeGuin piece. I'm going to see if there is a podcast/iTunes download of it. If so, it's going on the "required texts" list for my EN 102 class next semester.

Is this a different one?

I have to say, though I've never heard the expression, science fiction is the 'literature of ideas'.

It doesn't take more than a moment to go through your head and think of other genres - mysteries, romances, etc. - to understand that science fiction does, in fact, push new ideas and create new ways of thinking; there are no hard and fast rules in science fiction about anything - an excellent example is the 'Hitchhikers Guide to the Galaxy'. Not much in that book made practical sense, but the possibilities behind the writing are endless. Just my thoughts. ;-)

I took a very difficult class way back when on SF and fantasy. The thesis was that SF explored themes and ideas relevant to the present times, by using the device of cognitive estrangement. (!!!)

The plan was to give present reality a large twist and change in settings, so that real issues could be explored without the same everyday baggage that makes them harder to "see". It functions to give the reader a little distance. Also, I think you've said something like, without the constraints of historical facts that would obscure the story or idea.

Love your characters, ideas and stories!! Any way you go with it!

comments.article:
This isn't really related to your post, but I thought you might get a kick out of it! Someone made this for the "Pieces of Flair" Facebook application.



I checked out Dying of the Light, Fevre Dream and Inside Straight this year. Loved them! Thanks for ALL of your work :)

Interesting interview, and thank you for drawing our attention to it! A few things -

First, I liked your point about "The Road" - this is all the rage right now in academic literary circles (this coming from one embroiled in the English Degree steeplechase), yet it is certainly science fiction in so many senses... yet the book does not bear the "genre" identification.

In so many senses fiction is simply fiction... certainly there has been a deep proclivity of the so-called "literary fiction" genre of late to take on a narrowing bandwidth of topics (confessions of the young, promiscuous, bi-curious, suburban mini-philosophers!), but I don't think this is a permanent state of things.

Still... we've gotten to this place of the "sci-fi" section at the bookstore somehow, and I think, really, it has so much to do with the Science Fiction publishers ensuring that their work finds the eager hands of the limited public... after all, in periods of low readership, having that consistent base is useful, and in so many ways the separation model, ie "we are different because we read science fiction," works so well... and this commentary regarding the "literature of ideas" is, as you have pointed out, a play to that ideal. How sad that "genre writers" are seen as intrinsically second-class in their quality (Ms. Le Guin's point, and one I've certainly heard espoused by a number of writers working within the frameworks that most people would label F&SF), and that this style of writing is so discouraged in literary MFA programs at the moment (at least I've heard it is). I think Card said (for what it is worth) something about the "genre pit" (that may not have been his exact term) - ie this idea that once someone is labelled as being a genre writer, their destiny will forever be dominated by that label, etc. If that is so, its a terrible commentary on the compartmentalization of the publishing industry as a whole.

I was thinking recently... there is a battle worth fighting at the moment regarding these labels, and it is not, in my mind, so very necessary to convince literature-interested folks to give a science fiction book a chance - they actually seem rather willing to flit around between the stacks... so much as it is to persuade some of the more hardcore sci-fi-only-thanks guys to give Faulkner a chance, or Pynchon, or Heller, or Saunders... something in that scary, unguided and unlabeled "Literature" section. Perhaps then the links between all of the different sorts of literature will be a little more apparent to folks like Clive Thompson.

Food for thought, though maybe like potato-chips grade food.
Very nice, thanks!  :D

I'm still trying to understand the dividing line between fantasy and sci-fi. I know I like fantasy better than sci-fi, but to me, sci-fi covers a wider range of topics. I like to read about places that don't exist except in the writer's mind, but I also like to read stories that don't tax my mind too much trying to sound out the odd names that usually come alone with sci-fi. Two things turn me off when I open a book and scan the pages to see if i might want to read it - first, if I am in a fantasy mood, if I see any word that names something I know, like New York or England I immediately close the book. Second - the character names - if it takes me longer to sound out the names of the characters because they are just a jumble of consanants with a few vowels thrown in for good measure, I also close the book. I hold a BA in English and like to think I am a fairly intelligent person, but if at the end of the book I am still unsure that I am pronouncing the characters' names correctly, then the aforementioned sentiment applies and I probably will not read another by the same author.

To me, true fantasy should come fully from the author's imagination with no connection to the real world other than the ideas that make the plot flow, whether political or religious. (Sort of like Ice and Fire! Love it! Love it!) And yes, fantasy is all about ideas!

As for Ursula K Le Guin - harrumph! She said something once about another author - I won't name names - that really ticked me off, so I don't spend my hard-earned dough on her writing!

I have read almost fifty books so far this year and ninety percent of them have been pure fantasy. I might be alone in this, but I do like fantasy better than sci-fi. (Shrugs!) Sorry George!

Just one person's humble opinion.

That's too bad about Ms. Le Guin - her work is really fantastic, despite any negative feelings about her personality and opinions... I dare say that same outspoken personality informs the quality of her fiction, as it were... and she darts so quickly between science fiction and fantasy in her writing that the lines blur at points, which can be pleasant for fans of either genre (if you have a preference).

Not to minimize Mr. Martin's work (obviously I wouldn't even be posting this if I wasn't a fan, right?), but thought it was worth mentioning.

Right after college when the "fantasy" monkey was taking a firm perch on my shoulder, I checked the three books in the Earthsea series out of the library and only finished the first one. (That was before my sour opinion of Ms. Le Guin formed.)

I'm sure she is quite good, but I think that public people need to watch their public criticisms to a point. Just because she has big bucks and does something for a living I'd die to do, every person in the public eye is accountable for the impression they leave in their wake.

I met Christopher Paolini a few years ago and it might have been he was just stressed at the time, but I watched how he interacted with people and thought him rather rude to a point, (unless you were an eighteen-year-old girl, that is,) but I still read his last book. In my opinion, first impressions are as important as last impressions when you stand before the public eye.

As for our "Not A Blog" host: I met George over a year ago at a con and he is more gracious than you can imagine. I've met several authors and he is the most down to earth and personable of the lot of them.

You rock, George!
